document.title: History and Social Science Standards of Learning for Virginia Public Schools

857952D3D09448EAA41ECA1382F8152C.description:
analyzing the contributions of artists and philosophers of the Italian Renaissance, including
Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, and Petrarch.

15C80DD6D0DC4ABC8E7EF46DCFF5BF2F.description:
sequencing events related to the rise of Italian city-states and their political development,
including Machiavelli’s theory of governing; and

CB30349976BD445892AB89807A415BCA.description:
determining the economic, political, philosophical, and cultural foundations of the Italian
Renaissance;

1F3AEB23ADAF4F37B36E6CC8B1134983.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand the factors contributing to
the European Renaissance by

552FCB29BD22407EB7B0AD4A15FC2BFB.description:
examining the roles of people in each society, including class structures, family life,
warfare, religious beliefs and practices, and slavery.

D1C5264B59F5438CBC31458743C0E77C.description:
describing the Meso-American achievements in astronomy and mathematics, including the
development of the calendar and the Meso-American knowledge of seasonal changes to the
civilizations’ agricultural systems; and

3029DA94EBD14EE88DF222A09218B64C.description: describing the artistic and oral traditions and architecture in the three civilizations;

4110CAB739984C32A9B0A697C238BC34.description:
explaining how and where each empire arose and how the Aztec and Incan empires were
defeated by the Spanish;

2FB683513C6B4356B0553F72E09F7DF1.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand the Meso-American and
Andean civilizations by

3B643959DE3E44CF9DC077A0A38856CA.description:
explaining the importance of the Catholic church as a political and intellectual institution
and its effects on education, religious orders, preservation of languages and texts, and
philosophy.

702DF2B7D72E49DFBC3688EF58C21F2A.description:
describing the decline of Muslim rule in the Iberian Peninsula that resulted in the
expansion of Christian rule and the rise of Spanish and Portuguese kingdoms; and

7FB39AAC47F54002B3F8B100B246B4A1.description:
tracing the causes and course of the Crusades and the effects on the Christian, Muslim,
and Jewish populations in Europe and territorial claims;

4206DDDE35DF43A89716A8EBD1109EC8.description: analyzing the reasons for the Great Schism in 1054;

51F113B19A8C48979BB3DAC739375862.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to analyze the conflict and cooperation
between the Papacy and European monarchs by

F0A2ABDAA5F443B49099597EE3661B84.description: describing the growth of towns and trade as Europe emerged from feudalism.

02819B4DCE0D40969AE23D24023A2A46.description:
explaining the development and role of feudalism in the medieval European economy and
the role of the manor as the center of feudal relationships at the foundation of the political
order; and

59EAAD814C3C49C19132CADDC7D14880.description:
describing the spread of Christianity north of the Alps and the roles played by the early
church and by monasteries in its diffusion after the fall of the western half of the Roman
Empire; and

CAE1A6C31F494DC88E607A250E2413BD.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand the civilizations of
Medieval Europe by

C73719442EA14C62864B2D92186C7797.description:
analyzing the rise of a military society in the late 12th century and the role of the samurai in
that society.

A3DF4BA288CA4943857509EC5FCCB85C.description:
examining the ninth and tenth centuries’ golden age of literature, art, and drama and its
lasting effects on culture today, including Murasaki Shikibu’s Tale of Genji; and

C754E9260E754E928958298D9A5B8EB6.description: tracing the development of distinctive forms of Japanese Buddhism;

BD6CAD9BCD74422DABF4F6AEF108FA23.description:
discussing the reign of Prince Shotoku of Japan and the characteristics of Japanese society
and family life during his reign;

625AEE15CAC442E69FBBBF6FC39370D1.description:
describing the significance of Japan’s proximity to China and Korea and the intellectual,
linguistic, religious, and philosophical influence of those countries on Japan;

351624EDB3C8476281F775C137E50344.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand the civilizations of
Medieval Japan by

302AF03D1E684723BE5D2A72A38627C1.description:
describing the importance of written and oral traditions in the transmission of African
history and culture.

61A364D669B84BCB8E7C13540E506EE1.description: tracing the growth of the Arabic language in government, trade, and Islam; and

E0CDE2EE935B418197EC5FFA7E4C4C3A.description:
describing the role of the trans-Saharan caravan trade in the changing religious and cultural
characteristics of West Africa and the influence of Islam;

11233C5FA7EA405491E0E396107C9560.description:
analyzing the importance of family, labor specialization, and regional commerce in the
development of states and cities in West Africa;

6F9B3E272BFB4A91A6D78E63338CF810.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to describe the sub-Saharan civilizations
of Ghana and Mali in Medieval Africa by

1BA5E1191DCF4D219967E8655FFAD498.description: describing the development of the imperial state and the scholar-official class.

FBFEF51172404FB190ECECBE4BE6892E.description:
tracing the historic influence of the tea trade, the manufacture of paper, woodblock
printing, the compass, and the invention of gunpowder; and

5E96AEC7BEC542FAADF76841DC110C6F.description:
explaining the importance of overland trade and maritime expeditions between China and
other civilizations in the Mongol Ascendancy and Ming Dynasty;

57396ED308C24BC8A0EC9F41408ED5B6.description:
analyzing the influences of Confucianism and changes in Confucian thought during the
Sung and Mongol periods;

BB111A9E1E744991A10301F43C7F4121.description:
describing agricultural, technological, and commercial developments during the Tang and
Sung periods;

F6A8C3CB082542D9B4213ACEE292C3C9.description:
describing the reunification of China under the Tang Dynasty and reasons for the spread of
Buddhism in Tang China, Korea, and Japan;

D16CDFDDCC9240BBA4A588FF4752548B.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand the civilizations of China
in the Middle Ages by

4AEBF3480BB04B0ABF28F9553BB6D386.description:
describing the growth of cities and the role of merchants in Muslim society and the
expansion of trade routes in Asia, Africa, Europe, and the Indian Ocean and identifying the
products and inventions that traveled along these routes, including spices, textiles, paper,
steel, and new crops.

A45D1F2E75434149A82BB32C2356E4F2.description:
describing the expansion of territory under Muslim rule, the spread of Islam and the Arabic
language among people in these territories, and the cultural and religious acceptance of
Islam and the Arabic language; and

DAF3128B356D4E97AF791A7E06C2C015.description:
explaining the significance of the Qur’an and the Sunnah as the primary sources of Islamic
beliefs, practice, and law, and their influence in Muslims’ daily life;

845FF2099627436BBA2CD9B10D58EDBF.description: describing the origins, beliefs, traditions, customs, persecution, and spread of Islam;

193A20F2DF3C4FB699312912972829B7.description: The student will apply history and social science skills to understand Islamic societies by

F3DC1ABFA42D45A9B91E762BC6AA3BD6.description:
explaining the influence of Rome, including, but not limited to citizenship, slavery, Roman
law and guaranteed rights, Roman art, architecture, engineering, and philosophy.

65618736AFF8487490F04AFDC53B77AF.description:
describing the origins, beliefs, customs, and spread of Christianity, including the
persecution and eventual adoption and transmission of Christianity and the New Testament,
differences between the Eastern and Western churches, and the influence of Christianity
throughout Europe, Middle Asia, the Middle East, and North Africa; and

B2947C2AAF2F4CD1A1BCD8077AFBDCD9.description:
comparing and contrasting the political, social, and religious structure and development of
the Roman Republic and the Roman Empire;

2528A8E0E9AD4F7C8CC41762C2CA9A15.description:
describing the influence of geography on Rome’s development and the factors that
threatened territorial cohesion;

67BB39DE054B40B983B02066B4F53A2D.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand Rome and the Byzantine
Empire by

A5760600E151412CA1121D0669074209.description:
explaining the influence of ancient Greek contributions, including, but not limited to
science, art, architecture, philosophy, and mathematics in the present day.

90EE16AA81B04E789A5E7F0D310C97DF.description:
evaluating the significance of Alexander the Great’s conquest of Greece and the formation
and the spread of Hellenistic culture; and

A4B2EFD22E15461A80198C68DC887671.description: evaluating the causes and consequences of the Persian and Peloponnesian wars;

1B7DBD9DE1014243AD225E8CF7A8F762.description: describing the social, cultural, political, and economic aspects of ancient Persia;

C57A1D6E7BA24D28A0DF795AE48534BA.description:
describing the major geographic features of the region and analyzing the effect that
geography had on its development;

4FEF29B4706B457786395DD07C36768A.description: The student will apply history and social science skills to understand Persia and Greece by

98127A89C1194699810F9F5D381BCE22.description: describing the influence of Confucianism, Taoism, and Legalism.

23F033E696DA4204A1C3D922E45011F3.description: describing the social, cultural, political, and economic development of ancient China; and

EA1C1319E598471CA77901EE283640CF.description: describing the origins, beliefs, customs, and spread of Buddhism;

36825982C8DF4825B0A368E94D039780.description: describing the origins, beliefs, customs, and spread of Hinduism;

3B0AE02D762E48DF831148FA172FC7AE.description:
analyzing the impact of geography on the development of ancient India and China,
including locating them in time and place and describing their major geographic features;

DB4974C42F9F43A890F4D651C5756816.description: The students will apply history and social science skills to describe ancient Asian societies by

7189E49A02E74A22B3FD9F3F29332A6C.description: describing the development of the Phoenicians.

E536432B167B4D689A41079E3A855D5B.description:
describing the development of the Israelites and the origins, beliefs, traditions, customs,
persecution, and spread of Judaism; and

F6930BA852384782935B544EB2E79E4C.description: locating and explaining the development of Mesopotamia;

41AA00878B894B21B75BF54F3E400C2E.description: locating and explaining the development of Egypt and Nubia;

310355B495494FAF80B7D1D7E1A3EA71.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to describe early societies in the Fertile
Crescent by

AB46D758DFE94D408AE6E31C0C8525D8.description: Social, Cultural, Political, and Economic Development of Early Societies

CD57569CBDE946AD97B72152224684C2.description: analyzing how archaeological discoveries change current understanding of early societies.

DE524071D31144BF906CCC6396407337.description: analyzing how technological and social developments gave rise to sedentary settlements; and

EE614F655DF842FA8F9BBEA84B24B777.description: describing characteristics of hunter-gatherer societies, including their use of tools and fire;

2601104759A6492BBF5093A25BB5D1BB.description:
explaining the effect that geography had on the emergence and migration of hunter-gatherer
societies;

79F4DD8784F2452FA7217A3CC8AD3D49.description: describing the archaeological evidence of the first human and their geographic locations;

88366A26AED947B9BB1B1F7A14F8787A.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to describe the period from the Paleolithic
Era into the Neolithic Era by

80ED1DE929A94FC9A08D01EA5A8372C3.description: Paleolithic Era into the Agricultural Revolution Neolithic Era

28CA4193151944849E3AC070C49A7BF7.description:
contextualizing and corroborating sources to evaluate sources for credibility,
propaganda, and bias to determine patterns and trends to understand the ancient world.

A8F2F4258E17403598F8354A9F06A482.description: developing products that reflect an understanding of research and content; and

9870C2636EBD42D194FDAB0200CB2EA7.description:
engaging and communicating as a civil and informed individual with different
perspectives;

22E178981CD141399B05D5F119B3E7D7.description:
using economic decision-making models to analyze and explain the incentives for and
consequences of a specific choice;

B3F85F7E667F4E6783C9CD3E05DCB157.description: determining cause and effect to analyze connections;

F793E5FF14D949478AAF1822646F26BA.description: comparing and contrasting historical, cultural, economic, and political perspectives;

920B943619A3437BB690B16DD75AF0C2.description:
investigating and analyzing evidence from multiple sources to construct arguments and
draw conclusions;

1751B154FDA74211B2D0D3370EEC431E.description: questioning to construct arguments, using evidence from multiple sources;

8DE98B91F8794175A0841396C1C10B2C.description:
applying geographic skills to determine and predict patterns and trends of people,
places, and events;

18002E311BB8420283CD6FF58E86FE33.description: The student will apply history and social science skills to the content by
